question3b.value:
Self-reported intergroup contact (Cloutier et al., 2014), EMS/IMS (Plant & Devine, 1998), SDO (Pratto et al., 1994), feeling thermometers representing participants’ explicit racial bias, blatant dehumanization (e.g., Kteily et al., 2015) [assessed in subject pool pre-test]; Social evaluations of status, strength, and threat, “uniquely human” and “human nature” dehumanization (Haslam et al., 2006) [assessed in lab]

Note: while we predict that bias in pain sensitivity will predict bias in treatment over and above these measures, it may be the case that independently, one or more of these measures will also be related to a) bias in sensitivity and/or b) bias in treatment. While we will assess these relationships for the sake of comprehensiveness, these analyses will ultimately be exploratory.

question10b.value:
Spatial Frequency Task
1. Participants will complete a pain recognition task, in which they see 80 male targets (40 White, 40 Black; created using FaceGen Modeller Pro). Each trial will begin with a 500ms fixation cross. Then, participants will see filtered stimulus (Black or White face with BSF, HSF, or LSF filter) for 200ms, after which, participants will have 2000ms to report if the face is expressing pain. After a 500ms blank screen, the next trial will begin. Participants will make 480 (80 targets X 2 expression types X 3 filters) judgments. 24 additional catch trials (e.g., 100% painful expressions) will be inserted; 8 per block.
2. Trial will be divided across 3 blocks, in order to give participants time to rest between blocks to minimize fatigue.
3. All IVs are within-subjects, and all condition combinations are experienced in a repeated-measures fashion. 

Treatment Recommendation Task
1. Participants will see 40 male targets (randomly selected from the larger set of 80; 20 White, 20 Black; grayscale BSF). Each target will be presented making an ambiguous painful expression. Participants will be asked to provide treatment recommendations in order to relieve each target’s pain. Specifically, they’ll report how much of a non-addictive pain cream (from 0-20g) they would give to the targets.

Individual Difference Measures
1. Feeling thermometer measure (e.g., ratings of how warm or cold participants feel about 12 social groups on a scale of 0 to 100, into which “Black Americans” and “White Americans” are inserted randomly; collected in a pool-wise pretest)
2. Social evaluations of status, strength, and threat of 12 social groups, including black and white Americans
3. Intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014; collected in a pool-wise pretest)
4. EMS/IMS (Plant & Devine, 1998; collected in a pool-wise pretest) 
5. SDO (Pratto et al., 1994; collected in a pool-wise pretest)
6. Blatant dehumanization (Kteily et al., 2015; collected in a pool-wise pretest)
7. “Uniquely human” and “human nature” dehumanization (Haslam et al., 2006)

question5b.value: Data will be collected at the University of Delaware. We will recruit from the psychology subject pool (e.g., participants are Introduction to Psychology (PSYC100) students participating for research credit).

question6b.value: As this represents original research assessing the effects of spatial frequency manipulation on pain perception (and racial bias therein) for the first time, we must be somewhat heuristic in our sample size determination, though this investigation will provide a first estimate of the predicted effect size in subsequent studies. As such, we will recruit 100 participants, which will garner the necessary statistical power to detect a moderate effect size (e.g., r = .3) with 87% power.

question7b.value: We will check ONLY data exclusions after 20 participants have been run (see below). If this preliminary assessment confirms that an appropriate number of participants have passed criteria for inclusion, we will terminate data collection once (and not begin full data analysis until) 100 participants have been run. Once 100 participants have been run, we will once again assess exclusions, and run additional participants to complete the sample if needed.

question8b.value:
Non-differentiation of responses in the Spatial Frequency Task (e.g., the same response on 90% of trials or greater) will result in exclusion from analyses.

An additional 24 trials will be inserted (8 per block), which will depict 100% pain expressions (12 black targets, 12 white targets). Participants who don’t respond “Yes” on 67% of these trials (16 out of 24) will be excluded from analyses.

Participants whose average reaction time in the Spatial Frequency Task is two times the standard deviation across the sample will be excluded from analyses. 

Participants who fail to respond on 25% or more of trials will be excluded from analyses.

Demographic Exclusion: Only white participants will have their data analyzed for this project.

question9b.value:
After 20 participants are run, the exclusion-relevant data (e.g., average reaction times, catch trial responses, response differentiation) will be assessed to determine whether a preponderance of participants would end up being excluded. If more than 33% would be excluded, we will stop data collection and revise (e.g., shorten) the task.

After 100 participants are run, the exclusion-relevant data will once again be analyzed, in order to determine how many additional participants are needed to be run to reach 100, after exclusions.

question1a.value:
1. Overall, we predict a main effect of spatial frequency (low versus high versus broad spatial frequency): participants will be more sensitive to pain expressed by BSF versus LSF targets, (e.g., higher d’), and in return, more sensitive to pain expressed by LSF versus HSF targets. 

2. In a subsequent treatment recommendations task, we predict a main effect of target race: black targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than white targets.

3. We predict that differences in pain sensitivity for black versus white targets will be correlated with differences in treatment for black versus white targets – e.g., participants who are sensitive at recognizing pain on white (vs. black) targets will prescribe white targets comparatively more pain-relieving cream in a subsequent task. 

4. We predict that differences in pain sensitivity will facilitate the relationship between race and treatment recommendations in a within-subjects mediation analysis, over and above third variables described below.

question2a.value:
1. We also predict an interaction between spatial frequency and target race: participants will be more sensitive to pain on white (versus black) faces within the LSF and BSF targets (e.g., higher d’ for white vs. black targets), but there will be no effect of race within the HSF targets.

2. We predict that the relationships between pain sensitivity and treatment (tested via correlational analyses and within-subjects mediation) will vary by spatial frequency: these relationships will be stronger in the BSF and LSF conditions, versus the HSF condition.

question3a.value: Our stimulus manipulations (e.g., race – black or white; expression – pain or neutral; spatial frequency – BSF, HSF, LSF) are clear and concrete. In particular, our painful expressions have been extensively piloted (Mende-Siedlecki, Qu-Lee, Drain, & Goharzad, submitted; https://osf.io/2x8r5/), and the manipulations of spatial frequency information in faces have been tested across a large number of previous investigations (e.g., Goffaux et al., 2005; Goffaux & Rossion, 2006; Hayward et al., 2008). As such, no manipulation check is needed. An attention check (described in later section) will screen out participants who lose focus during the task.

question5a.value:
Recent work demonstrates that racial bias in pain care stems, at least in part, from a perceptual source (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). Racial bias in pain perception cannot be explained by low-level stimulus features, persists even when identical expressions of pain are rendered on computer-generated targets, and facilitates biases in treatment above and beyond explicit stereotypes and prejudice. Critically, this bias in pain perception arises from disruptions in configural face processing (Exps. 3 and 4, Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). When black and white faces were presented in an upright fashion, racial bias in pain perception was observed, but when face presentation was inverted, this bias was attenuated. Moving forward, we hope to obtain convergent evidence supporting the perceptual nature of this effect—specifically, that configural face perception (and its disruption) underlies racial bias in pain care.

Notably, configural processing is also associated with visual information in low spatial frequencies (LSF), while high spatial frequency (HSF) information facilitates featural processing (Goffaux et al., 2005; Morrison & Schyns, 2001). More broadly, LSF information is critical for typical emotion recognition—including perception of fearful (Winston, Vuilleumier, & Dolan, 2003; Vuilleumier, Armony, Driver, & Dolan, 2003; Mermillod, Vuilleumier, Peyrin, Alleysson, & Marendaz, 2009), threatening (Gao, LoBue, Irving, & Harvey, 2016), and indeed, painful facial expressions (Wang, Eccleston, & Keogh, 2017). 

If LSF information supports configural face processing, and interfering with configural processing attenuates racial bias in pain recognition, this bias should vary depending on whether HSF or LSF information is available. Specifically, we predict participants will be more sensitive to pain on white (versus black) faces when viewing LSF-filtered or BSF-filtered faces, but not when viewing HSF-filtered faces.

question6a.value: We predict an interaction between race and SF (e.g., participants will be more sensitive to pain on white (versus black) faces within the LSF and BSF targets, but no effect of race within the HSF targets.) That said, it is possible that we may observe racial bias in the HSF condition, too. While not what we’d predict overall, this alternate hypothesis would be in line with work suggesting that a) race might actually disrupt BOTH configural AND featural processing (Hayward et al., 2008; Hayward et al., 2013), b) and that both LSF and HSF information are important for the perception of emotion in general (e.g., Jennings, Yu, & Kingdom, 2017), and pain in particular (Wang, Eccleston, & Keogh, 2015).

question1c.value:
We predict a main effect of spatial frequency (low versus high versus broad spatial frequency): participants will be more sensitive to pain expressed by BSF targets (e.g., higher d’), compared to pain expressed by LSF targets, and more sensitive to pain expressed by LSF targets than BSF targets.

(Note: This represents the hypothesized directional effect #1 in A. Hypotheses.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of spatial frequency and target race.

question3c.value:
IV: spatial frequency filter (BSF vs. HSF vs. LSF)

DV: d’, pain recognition

question1c.value:
In a subsequent treatment recommendations task, we predict a main effect of target race: black targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than white targets.

(Note: This represents the hypothesized directional effect #2 in A. Hypotheses.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in one-way ANOVA assessing the effect of target race.

question3c.value:
IV: target race (black vs. white)

DV: treatment recommendation

question1c.value:
We predict that differences in pain sensitivity for black versus white targets will be correlated with differences in treatment for black versus white targets. In other words, participants who are more sensitive in recognizing pain on white (vs. black) targets will prescribe white targets comparatively more pain-relieving cream in the treatment recommendation task. Critically, this correlation will be stronger when the difference in sensitivity is assessed within the BSF and LSF targets, versus the HSF targets.


(Note: This represents the hypothesized directional effect #3 and hypothesized interaction effect #2 in A. Hypotheses.)

question2c.value: These predictions will be assessed via bivariate correlation and Steiger’s z-test for comparing dependent correlations.

question3c.value:
IV: d’ difference score (white minus black; e.g., sensitivity bias)

DV: treatment recommendation difference score (white minus black)

question1c.value:
We also predict an interaction between spatial frequency and target race: participants will be more sensitive to pain on white (versus black) faces within the LSF and BSF targets (e.g., higher d’ for white vs. black targets), but there will be no effect of race within the HSF targets.

(Note: This represents the hypothesized interaction effect #1 in A. Hypotheses.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a 2x3 ANOVA assessing the effects of spatial frequency and target race.

question3c.value:
IVs: spatial frequency filter (BSF vs. HSF vs. LSF) and target race (black vs. white)

DV: d’, pain recognition

question1c.value:
We predict that differences in sensitivity to pain on white (versus black) targets’ faces will facilitate the relationship between race and treatment recommendations in a within-subjects mediation analysis, over and above third variables described above (e.g., status, strength, explicit racial bias, dehumanization). Once again, we predict that this relationship will be stronger within the BSF and LSF targets, versus the HSF targets.

(Note: This represents the hypothesized directional effect #4 and hypothesized interaction effect #2 in A. Hypotheses.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a within-subjects mediation (Montoya & Hayes, 2017). If 95% confidence interval bounding the indirect effect of adaptation on treatment outcomes does not include zero, this will be taken as evidence supporting the prediction.

question3c.value:
IV: target race

DV: treatment recommendations, within-subjects mediators: white and black sensitivity scores, as well as covariates (white and black status judgments, white and black strength judgments, white and black threat judgments, white and black warmth judgments, white and black dehumanization)

question4c.value: The covariates listed (white and black status judgments, white and black strength judgments, white and black threat judgments, white and black warmth judgments, white and black dehumanization) represent measures of explicit stereotypes and explicit prejudice that may be linked to racial bias in pain perception or treatment.

attributes.title: A replication of "When conflict influences liking: The case of the Stroop task"

q1.value: A replication of  "When conflict influences liking: The case of the Stroop task" , Expirement 2c

q2.value: Josephine Thoß, Shereen Qedra, Alexandra Dünner, Franziska von Albedyll, Désirée Gehrka, Patricia Graf, Stefan Scherbaum, Vincent Zipper, Michelle Sophie Gappert

q3.value:
According to current research, cognitive conflict is associated with negative affect. Building on this assumption, we aim to replicate the study "When conflict influences liking: The case of the Stroop task [Experiment 2c]". In doing so we aim to confirm the previous study's results, deepening our current comprehension of this area of human behavior. 
We will share the assumption that participants will like polygons displayed after compatible Stroop trials better than those displayed after incompatible ones. 
Given our bigger sample size, we aim to find a more reliable effect.

q4.value: Our hypothesis is that polygons shown after Stroop conflict trials will be rated more negatively than those displayed after compatible ones.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

q7.value: Participants will be blind to the hypotheses.

question.value:
We have a 2x2 Within-Design with factor 1 (compatible vs incompatible trials) and factor 2 (response vs. prime conflict task).

Factor 1 (Compatibility) is manipulated within subjects.

Factor 2 (Prime Conflict Task) is manipulated within-subjects and uses a yoked experimental condition, meaning that the average response time in Condition 1 (response task) will be used to determine the length of stimulus presentation in Condition 2 (prime task).

q9.value:
The sequence of compatible and incompatible Stroop trials will be randomized within subjects.
The pairing of polygons with Stroop trial type (response vs prime condition) will be randomized across subjects, as well as the pairing of polygons to the incongruent vs congruent Stroop word condition. 
During the rating of polygons, the order of polygons will be randomized. 
Order of prime and response task will not be randomized, due to the fact that the prime condition relies on the response time of the response condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
Human participants will be recruited within the psychology bachelor course module "M4 - Experimental Practice" at the Technical University of Dresden, Germany. Participation in 2 of 5 experiments within the course module is mandatory for students of this module, hence participants receive course credit for participation. 

Vision tests will be performed upfront to ensure all participants have a normal (or corrected) vision and do not suffer from any form of color blindness.
 
Recruitment will start in February 2020 and will end when all participants have been tested.

q13.value:
We aim for a sample of 60 subjects. Data sets of participants with technical problems or effects of attrition will not be replaced by testing new participants. 
The final sample size is determined by the number of students participating in the module.

q14.value:
We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain at least .80 power. 
We were able to achieve an expected power .99 (based on a post hoc calculation using the data from the previous study).

question.value:
Subjects will work on a Stroop Task and will be shown polygons of different shapes after correctly responded trials (in response task condition) or after all trials (in prime task condition). 

We define Stroop Task as the challenge of being shown words describing different colors (e.g "red", "blue", etc) while the color of the text is either displaying the named color (e.g. "red" being written in red color = compatible condition) or a different one (e.g. "red" being written in blue color = incompatible condition). It is the participants' task to choose the color of the text that the word is written in. This will be implemented by displaying the names of the colors red, blue, green, and yellow on the screen, each related to a letter on the keyboard: v, b, n, and m, respectively. 

Task 1: Response conflict task.
Participants will perform the Stroop task with each word being displayed for 2000 ms. After each word, there will be a randomly chosen polygon presented for another 1000ms. 
There are 24 compatible and 24 incompatible Stroop words, appearing in a randomized order for each participant.

Task 2: Prime conflict task.
Participants will again be exposed to 'Stroop words', however, without having the possibility to respond to it. They will be given as much time to view the Stroop word as it took them on average to respond to them in the first task. After each word, there will be a randomly chosen polygon presented for 1000 ms. 
There are 24 compatible and 24 incompatible Stroop words, appearing in a randomized order for each participant.

The variable of interest will be the liking score. We will measure this by asking participants ‘How much did you enjoy the following polygon?’ (on a scale of 1–9 the degree to which they esthetically liked each polygon; 1 = Extremely disliked; 9 = Extremely liked). Participants are told to provide an intuitive response, and that there are no correct or wrong responses. 

We will also measure response times in the Stroop task (response task condition) to ensure that there is conflict (participants take longer to respond to the incompatible that on the compatible ones).
We will calculate the Stroop effect (rt-incompatible*rt-compatible) and liking differences (liking compatible* liking incompatible).

We will perform a repeated-measures analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the factors compatibility and response condition on liking ratings.

A dependent samples t-tests with the factor compatibility will be performed on RT of the response task condition.

q21.value:
We will make inferences based on p-Values. We will assume an alpha level of 0.05 for all analyses. 

Liking Scores: ANOVA, one-tailed t-Test
Stroop Effect: one-tailed t-Test

q22.value:
Participants with an excessive amount of errors (more than 30% of the trials) will be removed from the analysis for likely not having understood the instructions. 
The same applies to participants whose responses do not differ at all. There will be no replacement for those participants. 

The data of non-native speakers of German and participants with dyslexia will be tested for the Stroop effect. If found, their data will be included in the analysis, however, if not, their data set will be excluded from the analysis.

q23.value: Trials with incomplete or missing data will be left out of the analysis. There will be no replacement for those trials.

q25.value:
Training trials will be performed before the main part of the experiment.

Because there are 12 possible incompatible Stroop trials but only 4 compatible ones, all 4 compatible Stroops will be shown, but only 4 incompatible ones. Therefore, there will be 8 training rounds in total in randomized order.

registration_responses.q1: A replication of  "When conflict influences liking: The case of the Stroop task" , Expirement 2c
registration_responses.q2: Josephine Thoß, Shereen Qedra, Alexandra Dünner, Franziska von Albedyll, Désirée Gehrka, Patricia Graf, Stefan Scherbaum, Vincent Zipper, Michelle Sophie Gappert
registration_responses.q3:
According to current research, cognitive conflict is associated with negative affect. Building on this assumption, we aim to replicate the study "When conflict influences liking: The case of the Stroop task [Experiment 2c]". In doing so we aim to confirm the previous study's results, deepening our current comprehension of this area of human behavior. 
We will share the assumption that participants will like polygons displayed after compatible Stroop trials better than those displayed after incompatible ones. 
Given our bigger sample size, we aim to find a more reliable effect.
registration_responses.q4: Our hypothesis is that polygons shown after Stroop conflict trials will be rated more negatively than those displayed after compatible ones.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
registration_responses.q7: Participants will be blind to the hypotheses.
registration_responses.q9:
The sequence of compatible and incompatible Stroop trials will be randomized within subjects.
The pairing of polygons with Stroop trial type (response vs prime condition) will be randomized across subjects, as well as the pairing of polygons to the incongruent vs congruent Stroop word condition. 
During the rating of polygons, the order of polygons will be randomized. 
Order of prime and response task will not be randomized, due to the fact that the prime condition relies on the response time of the response condition.

We have a 2x2 Within-Design with factor 1 (compatible vs incompatible trials) and factor 2 (response vs. prime conflict task).

Factor 1 (Compatibility) is manipulated within subjects.

Factor 2 (Prime Conflict Task) is manipulated within-subjects and uses a yoked experimental condition, meaning that the average response time in Condition 1 (response task) will be used to determine the length of stimulus presentation in Condition 2 (prime task).

attributes.title: Do adaptation aftereffects associated with painful expressions differ as a function of race?
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: Yes, data collection is underway or complete

additionalComments.value: While this official registration is being filed after data was collected, a pre-registration document was created and posted on the associated OSF project page prior to data collection.

question2a.value:
Independent Variable 1: Race (Black vs. White)
a. Within-participant
b. Orthogonal

Independent Variable 2: Adaptor Expression (Pain vs. Neutral)
a. Within-participant
b. Orthogonal

question2b.value:
Dependent Variable 1: Valence evaluation
a. 6-point scale of (1- very negative to 6- very positive)

Dependent Variable 2: Treatment recommendations
a. Recommendation of 0-20g of pain-relieving cream

question3b.value: Social evaluations of status, strength, and threat (assessed in subject pool pre-test); feeling thermometers representing participants’ explicit racial bias, blatant dehumanization (e.g., Kteily et al., 2015), “uniquely human” and “human nature” dehumanization (Haslam et al., 2006), intergroup contact (Cloutier et al., 2014)

question10b.value:
Adaptation Task
1. Participants will complete a modified adaptation paradigm from Fox and Barton (2007), in which they see 40 male targets (20 White, 20 Black; created using FaceGen Pro). Each trial, participants will see an adapting stimulus (Black or White face with a neutral or painful expression) for 5s, followed by a mask for 50ms, then a probe stimulus (the same target with a neutral expression) for 300ms. Participants will report how positive or negative the neutral face is using a 6-point scale. Participants will make 320 (40 targets X 2 emotions X 4 blocks) judgments. One catch trial (e.g., a painful probe stimulus) will be inserted per block. 
2. Both IVs are within-subjects, and all condition combinations are experienced in a repeated-measures fashion. 

Treatment Recommendation Task
1. Participants will see 40 male targets (20 White, 20 Black). Each target has an ambiguous painful expression. Participants will report how much of a non-addictive pain cream (from 0-20g) they would give to the targets.

Individual Difference Measures 
1. Feeling thermometer measure (e.g., ratings of how warm or cold participants feel about 12 social groups on a scale of 0 to 100, into which “Black Americans” and “White Americans” are inserted randomly)
2. Social evaluations of status, strength, and threat (collected in a pool-wise pretest) of 12 social groups, including black and white Americans
3. Intergroup contact (adapted from Cloutier et al., 2014)
4. Blatant dehumanization (Kteily et al., 2015)
5. “Uniquely human” and “human nature” dehumanization (Haslam et al., 2006)

question5b.value: Data will be collected at the University of Delaware, and will recruit from the psychology subject pool (e.g., participants are Introduction to Psychology (PSYC100) students participating for research credit).

question6b.value: As this represents original research intended to establish a new effect (e.g., assessing adaptation aftereffects as a measure of racial bias in pain perception), we must be somewhat heuristic in our sample size determination, though this investigation will provide a first estimate of the predicted effect size in subsequent studies. As such, we will recruit 100 participants, which will garner the necessary statistical power to detect a moderate effect size (e.g., r = .3) with 87% power.

question7b.value: We will terminate data collection once (and not begin data analysis until) 100 participants have been run.

question8b.value:
1. Non-differentiation of responses (e.g., the same response on 90% of trials or greater) will result in exclusion from analyses.

2. One catch trial will be inserted per block – a trial on which a painful probe face is preceded by a neutral adaptor. Participants whose average response on these trials is not significantly lower than their average rating of neutral probe faces will be excluded from analyses. 

3. Participants whose average reaction time is two times the standard deviation across the sample will be excluded from analyses.

4. Demographic Exclusion: Only white participants will have their data analyzed for this project.

question9b.value:
After 20 participants are run, the exclusion-relevant data (e.g., average reaction times, catch trial responses, response differentiation) will be assessed to determine whether a preponderance of subjects would end up being excluded. If more than 33% would be excluded, we will stop data collection and revise (e.g., shorten) the task.

After 100 participants are run, the exclusion-relevant data will once again be analyzed, in order to determine how many additional participants need to be run to reach 100, after exclusions.

question1a.value:
1. We predict a main effect of adaptor (neutral versus painful): neutral targets will be rated more positively when preceded by painful adaptors, than when preceded by neutral adaptors.

2. In a subsequent treatment recommendations task, we predict a main effect of target race: black targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than white targets.

3. Finally, we predict that differences in pain adaptation effects for black versus white targets will be correlated with differences in treatment for black versus white targets – e.g., participants who show larger adaptation effects for white (vs. black) targets will prescribe white targets comparatively more pain-relieving cream in a subsequent task.

4. We predict that differences in adaptation aftereffects (e.g., our perceptual measure of racial bias in pain recognition) will facilitate the relationship between race and treatment recommendations in a within-subjects mediation analysis, over and above third variables described below.

question2a.value: 1. We also predict an interaction between adaptor and target race: the adaptation aftereffect observed for painful adaptors will be blunted in black (vs. white) targets, with no difference in race observer for neutral adaptors.

question3a.value: Our stimulus manipulations (e.g., race – black or white; expression – pain or neutral) are clear and strong, and have been extensively piloted in both cases. As such, no manipulation check is needed. An attention check (described in a later section) will screen out participants who lose focus during the task.

question5a.value:
Recent work demonstrated that racial bias in pain care stems, at least in part, from a perceptual source (Mende-Siedlecki et al., 2019). Racial bias in pain perception arises from disruptions in configural face processing, cannot be explained by low-level stimulus features, persists even when identical expressions of pain are rendered on computer-generated targets, and predicts biases in treatment above and beyond explicit stereotypes and prejudice. Moving forward, we hope to continue to obtain evidence supporting the perceptual nature of this effect.

Fixating on a face varying along a particular dimension (e.g., emotional expression) elicits perceptual aftereffects in the opposite direction (Webster & Maclin, 1999; Leopold et al., 2001; Fox & Barton, 2007). Such adaptation effects are modulated by racial group membership (Jacquet et al., 2008; Short et al., 2011; Michel et al., 2009; Bestlemeyer et al., 2010). Taken together, we predict that while painful expressions should yield adaptation aftereffects (e.g., neutral faces presented after painful adaptors should be evaluated slightly more positively), racial bias in pain perception should be evident at the level of aftereffects as well. Specifically, we predict that aftereffects will be smaller when preceded by black (vs. white) painful expressions.

question1c.value: We predict a main effect of adaptor (neutral versus painful): neutral targets will be rated more positively when preceded by painful adaptors, than when preceded by neutral adaptors. (This refers to Directional Prediction #1.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the effects of adaptor expression and target race.

question3c.value:
IV: adaptor expression (neutral vs. painful)
DV: probe face rating

question1c.value: We predict that differences in pain adaptation effects for black versus white targets (e.g., difference score: white pain adaptation effect minus black pain adaptation effect) will be correlated with differences in treatment for black versus white targets (e.g., difference score: white pain treatment minus black pain treatment). In other words, participants who show larger adaptation effects for white (vs. black) targets will prescribe white targets comparatively more pain-relieving cream in the treatment recommendations task. (This refers to Directional Prediction #3.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a bivariate correlation.

question3c.value:
IV: adaptation effect difference score
DV: treatment recommendation difference score

question1c.value: We also predict an interaction between adaptor and target race: the adaptation aftereffect observed for painful adaptors will be blunted in black (vs. white) targets, with no difference in race observer for neutral adaptors. (This refers to Interaction Prediction #1.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a 2x2 ANOVA assessing the effects of adaptor expression and target race.

question3c.value:
IVs: adaptor expression (neutral vs. painful) and target race (black vs. white)
DV: probe face rating

question1c.value: In a subsequent treatment recommendations task, we predict a main effect of target race: black targets will receive lower treatment recommendations than white targets. (This refers to Directional Prediction #2.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in one-way ANOVAassessing the effect of target race.

question3c.value:
IV: target race (black vs. white)
DV: treatment recommendation

question1c.value: We predict that differences in adaptation aftereffects (e.g., our perceptual measure of racial bias in pain recognition) will facilitate the relationship between race and treatment recommendations in a within-subjects mediation analysis, over and above third variables described above (e.g., status, strength, explicit racial bias, dehumanization). (This refers to Directional Prediction #4.)

question2c.value: This prediction will be assessed in a within-subjects mediation (Montoya & Hayes, 2017). If 95% confidence interval bounding the indirect effect of adaptation on treatment outcomes does not include zero, this will be taken as evidence supporting the prediction.

question3c.value:
IV: target race
DV: treatment recommendations
Within-subjects mediators: white and black adaptation scores
Covariates: white and black status judgments, white and black strength judgments, white and black threat judgments, white and black warmth judgments, white and black dehumanization

question4c.value: The covariates listed (white and black status judgments, white and black strength judgments, white and black threat judgments, white and black warmth judgments, white and black dehumanization) represent measures of explicit stereotypes and explicit prejudice that may be linked to racial bias in pain perception or treatment.

attributes.title: Exploring Moderators of the Effect of Child-Rearing Attitudes on Measures of Authoritarianism

q1.value: Exploring Moderators of the Relationship between Child-Rearing Attitudes and Measures of Authoritarianism

q3.value: The psychology and sociology of authoritarianism has been a subject of intense interest since the Second World War. Prominent articles have suggested a relationship between so-called authoritarian predisposition, as measured by child-rearing attitudes, and measures of manifest authoritarianism. This relationship is though to be moderated by a construct called normative threat, or a threat to the cohesion, unity, or success of an in-group. The relationship between authoritarian predisposition and manifest authoritarianism remains key to the modern sociological paradigm of authoritarianism; the psychological mechanism by which normative threat activates authoritarianism, however, has not been explored. We test the efficacy of self-esteem and a construct we defined as self-world fit as moderators of the relationship between authoritarian disposition and manifest authoritarian attitude. Should we find that self-esteem and self-world fit moderate the relationship between child-rearing attitude and manifest authoritarianism, this may suggest that self-esteem and self-world fit are some of the pathways by which normative threat activates authoritarianism.

q4.value:
It is hypothesized that:
1) (observational) The relationship between authoritarian predisposition, operationalized with a four-question child-rearing scale, and authoritarian attitude, operationalized using the Social Dominance Orientation and Right-Wing Authoritarianism scales, will be moderated by self-esteem. Lower self-esteem will lead to a stronger (more positive) relationship between disposition and attitude. 
2) (observational) The relationship between authoritarian predisposition, operationalized with a four-question child-rearing scale, and authoritarian attitude, operationalized using the Social Dominance Orientation and Right-Wing Authoritarianism scales, will be moderated by self-world fit. Lower self-world fit will lead to a stronger (more positive) relationship between disposition and attitude. 
3) (experimental) If our manipulation successfully lowers self-world fit or self-esteem, we expect to observe a stronger correlation between disposition (as operationalized above) and attitudes (as operationalized above) in the conditions of low self-world fit and self-esteem.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Experiment: 
Between subjects design with 1 factor (self esteem/self-world fit, but since we are not sure if our manipulation will alter self esteem, self-world fit, both, or neither, we consider this one factor)and 2 conditions (high, low) 

We will attempt to manipulate self-esteem and self-world fit using a novel and subtle manipulation. We will ask personal questions which relate to socioeconomic class and social and behavioral engagements. All questions will be multiple choice. In the 'low self-world fit' condition, the ranges of each answer choice will lead the majority of people to fall on the 'undesirable' end of the distribution; in the 'high self-world fit' condition, the ranges of each answer choice will lead people to fall in the 'desirable' end of the distribution. For example: participants in both conditions will be asked, "How often do you engage in more than a half-hour of intensive exercise?". In the low self-world fit condition, the answer choices are as follows: a) 0-6 times a week. b) once a day. c) twice a day. d) three times a day. e) more than three times a day. In the high self-world fit condition, the answer choices are as follows: a) never. b) once every few months. c) about once a month. d) a few times a month. e) more than once a week.

After the manipulation, we will measure authoritarian attitude (RWA, SDO), authoritarian predisposition (child-rearing attitudes), self-world fit, self-esteem, political preferences, and general demographics. If the manipulation is successful, we expect the 'high' condition to have higher self-esteem, self-world fit, or both. If the manipulation is successful, we expect the relationship between authoritarian predisposition and authoritarian attitudes to be stronger in the low condition than the high condition.

Observational:
We will further observe the efficacy of self-world fit and self-esteem as moderators of the relationship between child rearing attitudes and manifest authoritarian attitudes. This relationship will be tested using multiple regression. Additional tests may be run to assess self-esteem and self-world fit as moderators of the child-rearing SDO/RWA relationship.

q9.value: The subjects will be randomly assigned into one of two equally-signed conditions using Quadratics.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon MTurk. Participants will be compensated $0.35 for their involvement. Participants must be at least 18 years old, be located in the U.S., have HIT approval ratings higher than 95%, and have more than 5,000 HITS approved. If sufficient participants are not recruited within a few days, the pay may be raised, and the latter two (HIT-related) constraints may be lowered.

q13.value: We will recruit 225 participants per condition, 450 total.

q14.value: Based on a pilot we ran, the effect size seems relatively small, and 450 participants is an adequate balance of a sample size and economic considerations.

question.value: We manipulate the answer-choices to a set of questions participants are shown. In doing so, we are trying to subtly manipulate self-esteem and/or self-world fit.

Social Dominance Orientation Scale: An eight-item shortened scale from Sidanius et al. (2015).

Right-Wing Authoritarianism Scale: A six-item shortened scale from Bizumic and Duckitt (2018), called Very Short Authoritarianism scale.

Self-Esteem Scale: A shortened form of the Rosenberg Self-Esteem scale will be used (Rosenberg, 1965). The shortened form has four questions, based on results from a paper by Tambs and Roysamb (2014). In addition, the single-item self-esteem scale from Robins et al. (2001).

Self-World Fit Scale: This is a scale the authors of this paper have created. This version of it is a six-question scale.

Child-Rearing Scale: A four-question scale similar to the scale used in the ANES.

Works Cited

Ho, A. K., Sidanius, J., Kteily, N., Sheehy-Skeffington, J, Pratto, F., Henkel, K. E., Foels, R.,
and Stewart, A. L. (2015). The nature of social dominance orientation: Theorizing and
measuring preferences for intergroup inequality using the new SDO7 scale. Journal of
Personality and Social Psychology, 109(6), 1003-1028.

Bizumic, B., Duckitt, J. (2018). Investigating Right Wing Authoritarianism With a Very Short Authoritarianism Scale. Journal of Social and Political Psychology, 6(1), 129–150.

Robins, R. W., Hendin, H. M., and Trzesniewski, K. H. (2001). Measuring Global Self-Esteem:
Construct Validation of a Single-Item Measure and the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale.
Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 27, 151-161.

Rosenberg, M. (1965). Society and the adolescent self-image. Princeton, NJ: Princeton
University Press.

Tambs, K., Roysamb, E. (2014). Selection of questions to short-form versions of original
psychometric instruments in MoBa. Norsk Epidemiologi, 24 (1-2): 195-201.

We will be looking at Cronbach's alphas of all scales we use, to aid in assessing the efficacy of the scales. We will also look at the simple correlations between variables in our study (self-esteem and SDO/RWA -- we do not expect a correlation; self-world fit and SDO/RWA -- we do not expect a correlation; self-esteem and self-world fit -- we expect a positive correlation). These correlations serve to help understand the interaction of the constructs at play.

Observational Study:
Multiple regression to test self-esteem and self-world fit as moderators of the relationship between child-rearing and SDO and RWA. 
Binary and Trinary split of self-esteem and self-world fit to graph relationship between child-rearing and SDO/RWA with self-esteem and self-world fit at different percentiles (relationship between child-rearing and SDO for the 50% of subjects with lower self-esteem vs 50% with higher self-esteem; relationship between child-rearing and RWA for the 50% of subjects with lower self-esteem vs 50% with higher self-esteem; relationship between child-rearing and SDO for the 33% of subjects with lower self-esteem vs 33% with intermediate self-esteem vs 33% of subjects with high self-esteem; relationship between child-rearing and RWA for the 33% of subjects with lower self-esteem vs 33% with intermediate self-esteem vs 33% of subjects with high self-esteem; relationship between child-rearing and SDO for the 50% of subjects with lower self-world fit vs 50% with higher self-world fit; relationship between child-rearing and RWA for the 50% of subjects with lower self-world fit vs 50% with higher self-world fit; relationship between child-rearing and SDO for the 33% of subjects with lower self-world fit vs 33% with intermediate self-world fit vs 33% of subjects with high self-world fit; relationship between child-rearing and RWA for the 33% of subjects with lower self-world fit vs 33% with intermediate self-world fit vs 33% of subjects with high self-world fit). 
Fisher's R-to-Z transformation to test significance of binary and trinary split.
We may use plots to visualize some of this data.

Experiment:
Manipulation check: ANOVA to test effect of condition on self-esteem and self-world fit
First test of significance: Two-way ANOVA to test interaction between condition and child rearing attitudes in predicting authoritarian attitudes (RWA and SDO)
Second test of significance: Fisher's R-to-Z to test significance of difference in correlation between conditions.
We may use plots to visualize this data.

While we may run additional tests that are suggested by our findings, such tests would be post-hoc and exploratory and thus should not be considered part of this pre-registration.

q20.value:
SDO, RWA, Self-Esteem, Self-World Fit are measured as the sum of the responses to individual questions that compose them. 

The traditional child-rearing scale is a binary scale, where people select there view of whether one or another trait is more important for children to have. We aimed to make a more sensitive scale, so our measure of child-rearing attitudes is a six-point Likert scale; otherwise, the scale is identical to the child-rearing scales used elsewhere. We may collapse the six-point scale to a binary scale, should reviewers request that we adjust the data to reflect how it is commonly collected.

q21.value: We will use the standard p=.05 criteria for determining statistical significance. We will use a two-tailed test in our analyses.

q22.value: We will exclude data if 1) the subject fails our initial test of competence, which prevents the subject from participating in the study; or 2) the subject has universally, without discriminating between questions whatsoever selected the same answer choice (e.g., the top or bottom choice throughout). The initial tests of competence includes a captcha verification box, a prompt to select the most accurate statement, with the options being: "I am @ rabbit", "I am @ lion", and "I am @ human" in legible hand-writing, and a short blurb with a question that tests comprehension. These questions are intended to screen for bots and people who don't adequately speak English.

q23.value: Most of the data we request, the subjects are required to submit. We will keep all submissions (subject to the exclusion criteria) who respond to SDO, RWA, child-rearing attitudes, self-esteem, and self-world fit, regardless of whether political opinions and demographic information. We will not keep all participants who fail to respond to SDO, RWA, child-rearing attitudes, self-esteem, or self-world fit.

q24.value: After our main dependent variables and manipulation check, we ask a number of questions relating to political opinion (views about calls to 'lock up' political opponents and calling mainstream media 'fake news'; belief about whether the U.S. President should be constrained in their ability to make change, and belief in God). Furthermore, we include a shortened Big Five personality measure for exploratory purposes. We also request demographic information, including party affiliation, ideology, education level, age, race, sex, zip code, employment status, and income. We will use this for exploratory analysis, correlating demographic information and political views with measures of authoritarianism (SDO, RWA), self-esteem, and self-world fit.

q25.value: We expect a relatively small effect size, but believe that, should we find that self-esteem and/or self-world fit are real moderators of the relationship between child-rearing and authoritarian attitudes, this is an interesting and important fact.
